fields.headline: In praise of … typewriters
fields.bodyText: Hemingway glancing away from the Idaho hills, Orwell unaware of the cigarette in his mouth, and Dylan tapping obliviously as Joan Baez serenades him. Images of wordsmiths at typewriters have this in common: a look of deranged concentration. They were, after all, embarked on something difficult, a task where mistakes had consequences. When cut and paste required real glue, it was as well to think before writing; and – confronting a keyboard which couldn't tweet, poke or share – you'd half a chance of doing that. Perhaps such discipline will one day be venerated, and literary threads drawn through the 1880-1980 typewriting century. Until then, there are other reasons to mourn the last British machine rolling off the assembly line this week. The weight of the keys, the thud of the arms and the ring of return – all made typewriters a technology we could grasp. That sense struck a distinctive note on the keyboard of the imagination.
